facts.text: Appellant filed suit on October 24, 1942, for recovery of Rs. 2 lakhs and interest from date of suit against State of Travancore (now State of Kerala) for value of improvements on 160 acres of Cherikkal land from which he was wrongfully dispossessed.
Dispute over 160 acres and adjoining Cherikkal lands between Koodalvalli Illom (jenmi family) and Government of Travancore State since about 1848.

Appellant's father and appellant occupied the lands, made improvements by planting coconut trees, arecanut palms, pepper vines, rubber trees, jack trees, other trees, and constructing bungalow, huts, wells etc., in bona fide belief lands belonged to Illom.

Practice in Travancore: cultivators could enter unoccupied waste lands of janmies to cultivate and improve, paying rent; consent implied. Similar for Government lands before Travancore Land Conservancy Act 4 of 1091 (24-7-1916).
Under Act and Land Assignment Act, unauthorised occupants who made improvements had preferential claim for kuthakapattom or assignment.
Appellant applied to Conservator of Forests for registration of lands in his name; rejected on June 14, 1919 (Ext. A), stating land cannot be registered.

Illom instituted O.S. No. 126 of 1096 (January 1918) in District Court, Quilon, for declaration of title; appellant sought impleadment after registration rejection, rejected; suit dismissed 28-6-1109 (February 10, 1934); appeal dismissed September 27, 1943.
Government initiated ejectment proceedings against appellant in L.C. Case No. 112 of 1100 (1925 A.D.).
Appellant filed O.S. No. 156 of 1103 M.E. (1927-28 A.D.) in District Court, Quilon, against respondent for title to 160 acres and adjoining lands; prayed injunction for 100 acres, rejected.

Civil Miscellaneous Appeal No. 206 of 1110 M.E. (1934-35 A.D.) in High Court of Travancore against injunction rejection; Commissioner report (Part 13 of Ext. CC) listed improvements: bungalow, small houses, rubber estate, jack trees, mango trees, coconut trees etc.
Order for dispossession in L.C. Case No. 112 of 1100 M.E. passed July 24, 1939 (Ext. VI); appellant dispossessed, possession given to second defendant Nair Service Society Ltd. in August 1939.

Trial Court (Subordinate Court of Havelikkara) decreed Rs. 3000 for value of appellant's bungalow; rest of claim dismissed. Found possession commenced close to 1100 M.E., not 1030 M.E.; not bona fide after Illom suit dismissal; improvements mostly after L.C. proceedings stayed; no forfeiture order under s.9 conceded by Government Pleader.
Kerala High Court dismissed appeal (A.S. No. 216 of 1961) on March 2, 1965; affirmed trial court findings; trees not 'crop or other product' under s.9; no compensation for trees to trespasser.

Respondent contended: appellant encroached recently; entry not believing Illom land; no harassment, eviction per law; improvements by other squatters per Commissioner; forfeiture order passed (conceded not produced); duty to remove buildings before eviction; no possession of crops/movables taken.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellant's possession was bona fide, entitling him to compensation for improvements including trees under general law.
Whether trees are included in 'any crop or other product raised on the land' under s.9 of Travancore Land Conservancy Act, requiring notice of forfeiture.
Whether, absent s.9 forfeiture notice/order, appellant entitled to compensation for trees as trespasser.
Whether appellant evicted without notice to quit under s.9, entitling him to opportunity to remove trees.

petitioner_arguments.text: No order of forfeiture passed under s.9 of the Act; absent such order/right of forfeiture, entitled to compensation under general law for improvements including trees.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Travancore Land Conservancy Act s.9; general law

petitioner_arguments.text: Trespassed with bona fide intention to improve the land, qualifying as bona fide trespasser entitled to improvements compensation even without claim of title.
No notice to quit served under s.9; forcibly evicted without opportunity to cut and remove trees etc.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant encroached recently; possession not from 1030 M.E. but ~1100 M.E.; not bona fide as aware of govt claim post-registration rejection and Illom suit.
Improvements mostly by other squatters; forfeiture order passed in L.C. Case (though not produced); duty to remove buildings before eviction; no taking of crops/movables.
Trespasser position not better than tenant; no principle requires compensation for trees vested in State.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant's possession commenced after 1919 registration rejection; tried impleadment in Illom suit (rejected); aware lands govt or disputed; contravened s.5 of Act (no occupation without permission, punishable s.6); not bona fide trespasser.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Finding that possession bona fide or trespasser under bona fide claim unassailable.

court_reasoning.text: Trees not 'crop or other product raised on the land' under s.9; words qualify both, context of crop (emblements, annual products severed from soil); product means proceeds/yield, not attached trees; supported by Clark v. Gaskarth.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No obligation for forfeiture notice under s.9 for trees.

court_reasoning.text: Even under general law, deliberate wrongful trespasser (knowing no title, contravening Act) not entitled to compensation for trees; no authority for 'bona fide intention to improve' without title claim; dangerous principle; trespasser position not better than tenant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Vallabdas case does not support; quicquid plantatur solo, solo cedit applicable in principle.

court_reasoning.text: No pleading/allegation of no eviction notice or forcible eviction with police; plaint implies no opportunity for movables but not trees; no issue framed; cannot raise new point as knowing trespasser.

holdings.text: Appellant not bona fide trespasser; trees not covered by s.9 of Act; no compensation under general law for improvements/trees by knowing trespasser.
Trees excluded from 'any crop or other product raised on the land' in s.9; no forfeiture notice required.
Trespasser without bona fide title claim not entitled to compensation for trees planted.

precedents_cited.relevance: Trees/shrubs not 'product' in distress statute; confined to annual crops like those enumerated.

precedents_cited.case_name: Vallabdas Narainji v. Development Officer, Bandra
precedents_cited.relevance: Did not decide far-reaching contention of compensation for improvements by mere trespasser; govt not mere trespasser there.

statutes_cited.name: Travancore Land Conservancy Act 4 of 1091
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits unauthorised occupation (s.5); punishable (s.6); assessment (s.7); eviction, forfeiture of crops/products/buildings after notices (s.9); trees not products.

statutes_cited.name: Land Assignment Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Preferential claim for assignment to improvers.

statutes_cited.name: Travancore Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: No prosecution for resistance if imprisoned under s.9 proviso.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; affirmed High Court and trial court decrees allowing only Rs.3000 for bungalow; no substance in claims for trees/improvements compensation.
outcome.costs: No order as to costs, but court fee recovered from appellant

key_quotes.text: "trees are not included within the meaning of other products raised on the land in s. 9 of the Act and there is, therefore, no obligation on the Government to give notice of forfeiture under that section."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on s.9 interpretation excluding trees.

key_quotes.text: "the position of a trespasser cannot be better than that of a lawful tenant who having lost his possession cannot claim compensation or damages for anything erected on the land or any improvements made therein."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "No authority has been cited for this novel proposition, and if accepted, it would give validity to a dangerous principle which will condone all acts of deliberate and wrongful trespass."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dismisses 'bona fide intention to improve' as basis for rights.
